ranked_diseases.explanation: Prader-Willi Syndrome is characterized by hypotonia, global developmental delay, intellectual disability, and overweight/obesity, which are all present in the patient. Self-mutilation and chronic constipation are also commonly observed in this syndrome.

Bardet-Biedl Syndrome can present with intellectual disability, global developmental delay, and obesity. While hypotonia and chronic constipation are less common, they have been reported in some cases. Self-mutilation is not typical but may occur due to behavioral issues.

Smith-Magenis Syndrome includes intellectual disability, global developmental delay, hypotonia, and self-injurious behaviors. Overweight and chronic constipation are less commonly reported but may be present in some individuals.

Cohen Syndrome features intellectual disability, global developmental delay, and hypotonia. Overweight and chronic constipation are less common, and self-mutilation is not typically associated with this syndrome.
Alström Syndrome includes obesity and intellectual disability, but global developmental delay, hypotonia, chronic constipation, and self-mutilation are not hallmark features of this condition.
